channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Zelensky Visits Japan for G7 Summit, Seeking Military Aid
item.description: The Ukrainian leader sat down for “important meetings” with world leaders following his arrival in Japan, bolstered by President Biden’s decision to open a path for his country to get fighter jets.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine arriving in Hiroshima, Japan, on Saturday.

item.title: How Ukraine Reversed the Momentum in Bakhmut
item.description: Seizing an opening as Russia rotated troops, Ukraine pressed ahead with three days of maneuvers that gained ground on the flanks of Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Canada Wildfires Rage in Alberta and British Columbia
item.description: Wildfires raging in Alberta and British Columbia have created a sense of panic and fear, and forced thousands of residents to evacuate from their homes.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Jen Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Highway 43, a long stretch of Alberta highway, the thick layer of smoke from wildfires blanketed the road on Thursday.

item.title: Biden and G7 Summit Partners Struggle for Support Back Home
item.description: The relatively weak approval ratings for President Biden and his Group of 7 partners highlight the fragility of free societies facing deep political divides.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden and other Group of 7 leaders on Miyajima island on Friday. Most are struggling for support at home.

item.title: Video Shows Greece Abandoning Migrants at Sea
item.description: Video evidence shows asylum seekers, among them young children, being rounded up, taken to sea and abandoned on a raft by the Greek Coast Guard.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Sarah Kerr, Kassie Bracken and Nimet Kirac

item.title: U.S. Diplomats in Sudan Shredded Passports, Stranding Sudanese
item.description: Officials destroyed Sudanese passports on security grounds as they evacuated the Khartoum embassy. Now the passport owners are trapped in a war zone.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Sudanese army soldiers guard a checkpoint in Khartoum on Thursday.

item.title: Rockets Sent Israelis Running From the Beach. A Rare Seal Brought Them Back.
item.description: The incongruous arrival of a large and endangered monk seal has distracted Israelis from a period of violence and political unrest.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: An endangered and rare female Mediterranean monk seal napping in Jaffa, Israel, on Monday.

item.title: In a Sharp Reversal, Biden Opens a Path for Ukraine to Get Fighter Jets
item.description: The president told allied leaders that he would allow Ukrainian pilots to be trained on American-made F-16s, and is prepared to approve other countries’ transferring the jets to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Jim Tankersley, Michael Crowley and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden and other leaders at the Peace Memorial Park during a visit as part of the G7 Summit in Hiroshima, Japan, on Friday. He surprised his counterparts by telling them he was prepared to allow some European countries to train Ukrainian pilots on F-16 jets.

item.title: Cheetah Deaths Mar India’s Efforts to Reintroduce the Big Cats
item.description: The animals had been extinct for more than 70 years in the country, which has just begun a program that brought 20 cheetahs from Africa to a wildlife sanctuary.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Two cheetahs in quarantine at a reserve in South Africa last year before they were sent to the Kuno National Park wildlife sanctuary in India.

item.title: Tensions Flare in Georgia as Direct Flights Resume With Russia
item.description: Moscow also eased visa requirements for Georgians. But its actions have stirred fears in Georgia, which was invaded by Russia in 2008.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Tako Robakidze for The New York Times
item.media:description: Azimuth Airlines Flight A4851 was met by about 200 people protesting its arrival.

item.title: G7 Countries Borrow China’s Economic Strategy
item.description: Wealthy democracies rev up an effort to spend trillions on a new climate-friendly energy economy, while stealing away some of China’s manufacturing power.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Ana Swanson
item.media:description: President Biden with other Group of 7 leaders in Hiroshima, Japan, on Friday.

item.title: He Promised Change in Thailand. But Will He Be Allowed to Lead?
item.description: Pita Limjaroenrat led his party to victory in the Thai election and seems poised to become the next prime minister, unless the military blocks him.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pita Limjaroenrat, leader of Thailand’s Move Forward Party, at the party headquarters in Bangkok on Thursday.

item.title: Floods in Northern Italy Kill at Least 14
item.description: At least 14 people died and thousands were left homeless after some areas received half their annual rainfall in 36 hours in a region that had only recently finished rebuilding after a 2012 earthquake.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani

item.title: Tsunami Warning After Earthquake in South Pacific
item.description: After a 7.7 magnitude earthquake was recorded, a U.S. agency warned that waves as high as 10 feet could hit Vanuatu. But it later downgraded the estimate, and no major damage was reported.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The coastline in Port Vila, Vanuatu.

item.title: The Cannes Film Festival
item.description: Among the films premiering are features from Martin Scorsese, Wes Anderson and Todd Haynes.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Alberta Fires Rage While Election Ignores Global Warming
item.description: For politicians, discussing climate change in a province enriched by oil money is fraught.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Jen Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction left behind by wildfires in Drayton Valley, Alberta.

item.title: At G7 Summit, Leaders Wrangle on Coal, Natural Gas and Climate
item.description: The U.S. finds itself caught between defending President Biden’s climate change agenda and aiding allies intent on increasing their access to fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich, Lisa Friedman and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Group of 7 leaders at the Itsukushima Shrine in Japan on Friday. Their final communiqué only modestly modified previous language on natural gas investment.

item.title: Building Boom on Mykonos Reveals ‘Wretched’ Side of Greece’s Recovery
item.description: Investors are eager to cash in on soaring demand for luxury properties, but an attack on an archaeologist investigating building violations brought a darker underbelly to light.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman and Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Marco Arguello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction overlooking Panormos Beach and the Principote beach club.

item.title: Why the Leaders of Turkey and Thailand Have an Interest in Elections
item.description: Turkey and Thailand held two huge elections this week, both with uncertain outcomes. Each shows some of the benefits that elections can hold for leaders who have amassed power with the tools of the state.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election committee officials counting the envelopes that contained ballots after the presidential and parliamentary elections in Turkey, on Sunday.

item.title: 95-Year-Old Australian Woman Is Tasered by Police
item.description: She was holding a knife, but weighs 95 pounds and uses a walker. The episode, which took place in a care facility, prompted outrage, questions and a police investigation.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Lukas Coch/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Yallambee Lodge, an aged care facility in Cooma, Australia, on Friday.

item.title: 1923: Germany Seizes French Plane
item.description: Paris claimed a violation of the Treaty of Versailles after the German authorities impounded an aircraft that been forced to land outside Nuremberg because of engine trouble.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Russia says its defense minister visited the Zaporizhzhia area of southern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops earlier this year in the Zaporizhzhia region, which is considered a likely focus of Ukraine’s looming counteroffensive.

item.title: Liz Truss, Britain’s Briefest Prime Minister, Meets Taiwan’s Leader
item.description: Liz Truss, the former British prime minister, met Taiwan’s leader, who has sought to push back against China’s efforts to isolate the island democracy.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen meeting with former British Prime Minister Liz Truss in Taipei, Taiwan, on Friday.

item.title: Averting a Debt Limit Crisis
item.description: Both parties seem more willing to compromise on the debt limit.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: House Speaker Kevin McCarthy this week.

item.title: Zelensky Attends Arab League Summit in Saudi Arabia
item.description: Addressing an Arab League summit in Saudi Arabia, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged Arab nations to stand with him against Russia and called out their reluctance to take sides in the war.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Saudi Press Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A handout photo shows President Volodymyr Zelensky in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia where he participated in the Arab League summit on Friday.

item.title: How Hillsong, a Hip Megachurch, Became Entangled in Scandal
item.description: A new documentary series explores the history of Hillsong, known for its celebrity congregants and fashionable trappings before being struck by a series of scandals.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: A Hillsong service at the Belasco, a venue in Los Angeles, in 2014. The church was known for drawing young people to its services in big cities.

item.title: A South Korean Poet’s Work Honors Cats
item.description: The South Korean writer Hwang In-suk feeds stray cats on late-night walks through Seoul. The routine informs her poems about loneliness and impermanence.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Jun Michael Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’ve found worlds that I wouldn’t have found if I had not been feeding cats at night,” said the Seoul-based poet Hwang In-suk.

item.title: Russia Targets Kyiv for 10th Time This Month
item.description: The attacks come as a widely anticipated Ukrainian counteroffensive looms.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: A searchlight over Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, during a Russian drone attack overnight Friday.

item.title: Biden Pays Silent Tribute to Victims of Hiroshima Bomb
item.description: The president joined other leaders in laying wreaths at a memorial to the first wartime use of a nuclear weapon, amid growing fears that one could be used again.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Biden and other world leaders after laying wreaths at the Hiroshima Peace Memorial on Friday.

item.title: We Want to Hear From Australia Letter Readers
item.description: What should we be covering? Are there stories that the rest of the world should know about? Let us know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Melbourne skyline in the early morning light in April.

item.title: Ukraine arrests a top judge as the country’s corruption scandal grows.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Yan Dobronosov/Global Images Ukraine, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Vsevolod Knyazev, the chief of Ukraine’s Supreme Court, in court on Thursday after his arrest on corruption charges.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Negotiations over the U.S. debt limit.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Some Democrats have pushed back on a deal that President Biden might make.

item.title: Zelensky to Attend G7 Meeting in Japan
item.description: The Ukrainian president’s attendance at the meeting comes after President Biden opened the door to other nations training Ukrainian pilots and sending their F-16s to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Paris on Sunday.

item.title: Russia Fires Missiles at Kyiv as Crimea Train Derails
item.description: Ukrainian officials did not claim responsibility for a train derailment on the occupied peninsula, but it was the latest in a series of explosions hitting the railways and supply lines of Russia’s war machine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: An explosion of a missile is seen in the sky over the city during a Russian missile strike in Kyiv on Wednesday.

item.title: FDA Panel Recommends RSV Vaccine to Protect Young Infants
item.description: A committee of experts voted in favor of a new shot administered to pregnant women, one in a series of new ways to arm the very young against a life-threatening virus.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Alex Kormann/Star Tribune, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A 2-month-old in Minnesota was examined for respiratory syncytial virus after she was showing symptoms in 2020. The new vaccine would be given to pregnant women before birth.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Dueling Summits
item.description: Also, Meta publicly released its latest A.I. technology.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Chinese President Xi Jinping at a signing ceremony ahead of the China-Central Asia Summit in Xi’an, China, on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Arrests a Top Judge as Crackdown on Corruption Expands
item.description: At least three more Supreme Court judges, in addition to the chief justice, have been implicated in a growing bribery case, prosecutors say.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Yan Dobronosov/Global Images Ukraine, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Vsevolod Knyazev, the chief of Ukraine’s Supreme Court in court on Thursday after he was arrested on corruption charges.

item.title: Harry and Meghan Seek Both Privacy and Publicity After Paparazzi Car Chase
item.description: Their pursuit by paparazzi in New York shows that neither leaving Britain nor having a police escort shields them from unwanted attention.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Kevin Mazur/Getty Images Ms. Foundation for Women
item.media:description: Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, at the Ms. Foundation Women of Vision Awards in New York on Tuesday.

item.title: Gary Prado Salmón, Bolivian Captor of Che Guevara, Dies at 84
item.description: An army captain, he led the operation that tracked down the Communist guerrilla who had helped lead the Cuban revolution and was trying to foment one in Bolivia.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Gen. Gary Prado Salmón in 2007. Forty years earlier, his unit had been hunting the guerrillas for months when he received a tip from a farmer.

item.title: England’s Water Companies Vow to Clean Up Their Sewage Dumping Act
item.description: Private firms apologized for not doing more to prevent the release of untreated sewage into rivers and seas and pledged to invest 10 billion pounds to fix the problem.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A sewage overflow outlet that discharges into the River Thames in London last year. Environmental groups have questioned why water companies had been allowed to dump so much sewage for so long.

item.title: A Plane Crashed in the Amazon. Did Four Children Survive?
item.description: Colombia’s president announced that the children had been found alive after the May 1 crash. But now it’s unclear if rescuers had actually made contact with them.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Jack Nicas
item.media:description: A photo released by the Colombian military showed a plane that crashed in the forest in a rural area near Solano.

item.title: Syria’s Assad Rejoins Arab League for First Time in 13 Years
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad was shunned over atrocities committed in Syria’s civil war, but on Friday he is expected to join an annual summit of Arab leaders for the first time in 13 years.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A poster for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria hangs on a destroyed shopping mall in the war-ravaged city of Homs in 2014.

item.title: Israelis March Through Jerusalem, Raising Tensions in a Divided City
item.description: The annual parade marks the unification of the city after Israel captured East Jerusalem in 1967. Israelis see it as a celebration, but Palestinians consider it an insult, and it was marred by incitement against Arabs.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Israelis with flags near Damascus Gate, the entrance to Jerusalem’s Old City, on Thursday.

item.title: Sudan’s War Could Go in Many Directions. We Look at Some Scenarios.
item.description: As American-led peace efforts flounder, experts warn that Sudan risks spiraling into a state of anarchy akin to its most chaotic neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: A market on fire on Monday in Omdurman, a city across the River Nile from the Sudanese capital, Khartoum.

item.title: What Is the F-16 Fighter Jet and Why Does Ukraine Want It?
item.description: The versatile and lightweight American warplane is seen by many of Ukraine’s allies as an important deterrent against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Anushka Patil
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Remko de Waal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Britain and the Netherlands are pushing for F-16 fighter jets for Ukraine.

item.title: Cyclone Aid Stalled in Myanmar: ‘I Just Hope We Get Help Before We Die’
item.description: Aid groups in the war-torn country say they are having trouble gaining access to areas affected by the storm without approval from the junta.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Sai Aung Main/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: One of the places hardest hit by Cyclone Mocha was the area around Sittwe, Myanmar, where many Rohingya camps are located.

item.title: Ukraine is expected to dominate discussions at the G7 summit.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden and some members of his administration meeting with Prime Minister Kishida Fumio of Japan and his team in Hiroshima on Thursday.

item.title: Prescription Drug Shortages
item.description: Many Americans can’t get the medications they need.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times

item.title: Singapore Hangs Man in Second Drug-Related Execution in Three Weeks
item.description: The man had been sentenced to death for possessing less than 3.5 pounds of cannabis, a punishment that human rights groups condemned as grossly excessive.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Singapore has long taken a harsh stance toward drug offenses.

item.title: Ukraine and China Will Dominate G7 Summit, but a New Threat Lurks: A.I.
item.description: The leaders are expected to hold their first talks on a common regulatory approach to generative artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden departing Joint Base Andrews in Maryland on Wednesday for his trip to Hiroshima, Japan, for the Group of 7 summit.

item.title: Another Casualty in Ukraine: Teenage Years
item.description: In a battered Ukrainian city, the war has stolen the normal experiences of teenage life. The youths mostly use humor to deal with the ferocity of the fighting around them.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Denys, left, and Mykyta walking past a shell-damaged apartment building as their friends follow them in Sloviansk.

item.title: A Centuries-Old Mystery: Did This Elusive Viking City Exist?
item.description: Was a “medieval New York” called Jomsborg a literary fantasy or a historical reality? New archaeological discoveries may provide a clue.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A recreated “Slavs and Viking” settlement, with medieval craft demonstrations, re-enactments and guided tours in Wolin, Poland.

item.title: How the G7 Oil Price Cap Has Helped Choke Revenue to Russia
item.description: Group of 7 leaders are prepared to celebrate the results of a novel effort to stabilize global oil markets and punish Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden with the other Group of 7 leaders during their summit last year in Germany. Ahead of the meeting, U.S. officials sought to persuade other nations’ leaders to try to cap the price that Russia could command for oil.

item.title: Why Xi Jinping Is Strengthening Ties With Central Asia
item.description: Xi Jinping of China is meeting with leaders of five countries in Central Asia, a region crucial to his geopolitical ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, at a signing ceremony on Wednesday before the China-Central Asia Summit in Xi’an, China.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Rising global temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Among the risks from rising temperatures are intensified droughts and wildfires.

item.title: Ukraine’s Allies Wrangle Over Sending F-16 Fighter Jets
item.description: The United States is resisting a European push for the powerful fighters. But will it relent, as it did before with tanks, rocket launchers and air defense missiles?
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Remko De Waal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Dutch F-16 jet fighter landing at Volkel air base in the Netherlands. Britain and the Netherlands are leading a European push to send the jets to Ukraine.

item.title: French Resistance Fighter Goes Public About Execution of German P.O.W.s
item.description: Forty-seven soldiers were shot dead and secretly buried shortly after D-Day, a veteran says. The story was hidden for decades.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Edmond Réveil, a former French Resistance fighter, said he had witnessed but did not participate in the mass execution of German soldiers during World War II.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: The G7
item.description: Also, hot years ahead as global temperatures rise.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: U.S. President Joe Biden departs Joint Base Andrews, Md. enroute to Elmendorf Air Force Base, Anchorage, Alaska before continuing to his final destination, Hiroshima, Japan where he will participate in a G7 Summit working session on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia Renew a Deal to Allow Ukraine to Ship Grain
item.description: Russia last year blocked exports of Ukrainian grain across the Black Sea, a vital part of the global food supply, but they resumed last summer under a fragile pact.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Gulsin Harman
item.media:description: Grain being loaded at a port in Izmail, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: He Lost Turkey’s Presidential Election, but Could Swing the Runoff
item.description: Seen by some as spoiler but by others as a kingmaker, Sinan Ogan, the far-right candidate who came in third in the vote, says he is being courted by the two finalists: the sitting president and his challenger.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:description: Sinan Ogan, center, is surrounded by supporters in Ankara this month.

item.title: Trounced, Conservatives Feel Voters’ Wrath in English Heartlands
item.description: Defections in the once solidly Conservative southern “blue wall” drove large losses in recent municipal elections.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Olivia Harris for The New York Times
item.media:description: George Blundell, 22-year-old newly elected member of Windsor and Maidenhead Council, collecting litter with his girlfriend, in Maidenhead, England, on Saturday.
